AGENCY_NAME: Alabama Licensing Board for General Contractors
SPECIAL_NOTES: None

AGENCY_NAME: Alaska Dept. of Commerce, Community, & Economic Dev.
SPECIAL_NOTES: State license required for contractors. License numbers are numeric (e.g. 5–6 digits).
Search via ROC web portal (JavaScript-driven). License numbers are six digits.
State license required. License numbers can be up to ~10 digits (e.g. 0022880113).
License number is numeric (1–8 digits).
No state general contractor license (state does not license general contractors) – check local city/county regulations.
HIC registration required for home improvement contractors. License numbers begin with “HIC.” followed by 7 digits.
Delaware requires a state business license for contractors. License/registration ID is issued (e.g. 10-digit number).

AGENCY_NAME: Florida Dept. of Business & Professional Regulation
SPECIAL_NOTES: License format includes a 3-letter code + 6 digits (e.g. “CGC” for Certified General Contractor).

AGENCY_NAME: GA State Licensing Board for Residential & General Contractors
SPECIAL_NOTES: State license required for general contractors. License numbers are numeric (5–6 digits).

AGENCY_NAME: Hawaii Dept. of Commerce & Consumer Affairs (PVL)
SPECIAL_NOTES: Hawaii licenses: “A” (General Engineering), “B” (General Building), or “C” (Specialty) prefix + 5 digits. Example: B-12345.
No state general contractor license (Idaho does not license general contractors at state level).

AGENCY_NAME: IL Dept. of Financial & Professional Regulation (IDFPR)
SPECIAL_NOTES: Illinois has no state general contractor license; a state license is required only for specific trades (e.g. Residential Roofing, license format “104-XXXXXX”).
No state general contractor license (licensing handled at local level; only state‐licensed trades are plumbing, etc.).

AGENCY_NAME: Iowa Division of Labor – Contractor Registration
SPECIAL_NOTES: Contractors must register with Iowa Workforce Dev. (Division of Labor). Not a license (registration number issued upon compliance).
No state general contractor license (local licensing only). Note: Kansas requires state registration for roofing contractors (Kansas Roofing Registration Act).
No state general contractor license (licensing/registration is handled by local authorities; only certain trades like HVAC/electrical have state licensing).

AGENCY_NAME: Louisiana State Licensing Board for Contractors
SPECIAL_NOTES: State license required for contractors. License numbers are typically 4–5 digits.
No state general contractor license (no state licensing or registration for general contractors).

AGENCY_NAME: Maryland Dept. of Labor – Home Improvement Commission
SPECIAL_NOTES: Maryland requires a Home Improvement Contractor license for work on existing homes. License numbers are six digits (MHIC# on license).

AGENCY_NAME: Massachusetts Board of Building Regulations & Standards
SPECIAL_NOTES: State CSL required for structural work on buildings. (Mass also has a Home Improvement Contractor registration for other residential work.)

AGENCY_NAME: Michigan Dept. of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs
SPECIAL_NOTES: State license required for residential builders/contractors. License numbers are numeric (6 digits).
State license required for residential contractors. License format: two-letter prefix (license class) + 6 digits (e.g. “BC” for Building Contractor).
State license required (separate classifications for residential & commercial). License numbers are 5 digits, sometimes with suffix (e.g. “-SC”).
No state general contractor license (Missouri does not license general contractors; licensing is handled by cities/counties).
Contractors must register with DLI if they have employees (registration ensures workers’ comp compliance). Registration ID ~5 digits.
Contractors must register with Nebraska DOL. Not a license (registration for all contractors; proof of insurance required).
State license required (issued by NV Contractors Board). License numbers are typically 5 or 6 digits.
No state general contractor license (New Hampshire does not license general contractors at state level).

AGENCY_NAME: New Jersey Division of Consumer Affairs
SPECIAL_NOTES: State registration required for home improvement contractors. Registration numbers begin with “13VH” followed by 8 digits.

AGENCY_NAME: NM Regulation & Licensing Dept. – Construction Industries Div.
SPECIAL_NOTES: State license required for contractors (with annual $≥7.2k). License numbers are 5 digits (classification like GB-98 is separate).
No state general contractor license (licensing is handled by city/local government, e.g. NYC).

AGENCY_NAME: NC Licensing Board for General Contractors
SPECIAL_NOTES: State license required for general contractors (Classes Limited, Intermediate, Unlimited). License numbers are generally 5 digits.

AGENCY_NAME: ND Secretary of State – Contractor Licensing
SPECIAL_NOTES: State license required (classes by project size). License numbers are 5 digits; license class (A, B, C, D) is designated separately.
No state general contractor license (Ohio does not license general contractors at state level).
No state general contractor license (Oklahoma does not license general contractors; state licenses only certain trades).
Residential/commercial contractors must be licensed with CCB. License number is six digits. Search may return multiple results for partial queries.

AGENCY_NAME: PA Office of Attorney General – Home Improvement Reg.
SPECIAL_NOTES: Home Improvement Consumer (HIC) registration required for contractors. Verification site uses CAPTCHA, preventing automation without solver.
Contractors must register with the state CRLB. Registration certificate number is ~6 digits.

AGENCY_NAME: SC Dept. of LLR – Residential Builders Comm.
SPECIAL_NOTES: State license required for residential builders and general contractors (via LLR). License numbers are numeric (5–6 digits).
No state general contractor license (South Dakota does not license general contractors at state level).

AGENCY_NAME: TN Dept. of Commerce & Insurance – Licensing Board
SPECIAL_NOTES: State license required for contractors (Classes A, B, C – based on project size). License numbers are 5–8 digits (often zero-padded to 8).
No state general contractor license (Texas does not license general contractors at state level).
State license required (general contractors and specialty contractors). License format: 6 digits + “-5501” (professional code for contractors).
No state general contractor license (Vermont has no statewide contractor licensing; only certain trades like electricians are licensed).

AGENCY_NAME: Virginia Dept. of Professional & Occupational Reg.
SPECIAL_NOTES: State license required (Class A, B, or C based on project cost). License numbers are 10 digits beginning with “27”.
Verification requires JavaScript (interactive L&I portal). License/registration format is 12 characters (e.g. up to 8 letters, 3 digits, 2 letters).
State license required (issued by Division of Labor). License numbers begin with “WV” followed by 6 digits (e.g. WV000525).

AGENCY_NAME: Wisconsin Dept. of Safety & Professional Services
SPECIAL_NOTES: State registration required for dwelling (residential) contractors. Registration ID is 7 digits.
No state general contractor license (Wyoming does not license general contractors; only certain specialties like electrical and well drilling have state boards).
